headline: A Comprehensive Timeline of Ancient Chinese History
text: (A work in progress)
mediaCaption: © 1996-2014 National Geographic Society.

headline: Neolithic Cultures
text:
Primarily characterized by the production of stone tools, pottery, textiles, houses, burials, and jade objects. Current archaeological research suggests that roughly sixty Neolithic cultures existed (most of which have been named for the archaeological site at which artifacts were discovered) prior to the earliest historical records. Attempts at mapping Neolithic China have typically grouped the various archeological cultures by geographic location in relation to the courses of the Yellow River in the north and the Yangzi River in the south. Additionally, some scholars group Neolithic culture sites into two broad cultural categories: the Yangshao cultures in central and western China, and the Longshan cultures in eastern and southeastern China.

• Read more at the Princeton University Art Museum
mediaCaption: Maps courtesy of the Princeton University Art Museum's Asian Art Collection online resources.

headline:
仰韶文化
Yangshao Cultures
text:
The Neolithic sites and associated cultures which occupied the northern central plains are collectively known as the Yangshao cultures. Well known for its painted pottery, this is the group most often represented in western museum collections of Asian art. It is suggested that these cultures flourished primarily in the provinces of Henan, Shaanxi and Shanxi.

• Read more at the Princeton University Art Museum and the Asian Art Museum
mediaCaption:
Painted pottery, Yangshao Culture (a. 5000-3000 BCE).
Image courtesy of the University of British Columbia's Department of History

headline:
马家窑文化
Majiayao Cultures
text:
The Majiayao cultures occupied much of the upper Yellow River region, from Shaanxi province westward along the Wei River to Lanzhou, Gansu province, spreading along the upper reaches of the Yellow River and into Qinghai province. Characterized chiefly by polished red earthenware pottery, often bearing complicated finishes painted in black, the Majiayao cultures subsisted via agricultural and hunting-gathering means; while their agricultural activity seem highly remniscient of Yangshao tradition, the Majiayao differed in their strong hunter-gatherer tradition and possible practice of pastoralism.

Phases of Majiayao culture included Majiayao (ca. 3100–ca. 2700 B.C.), Banshan (ca. 2600–ca. 2300 B.C.), and Machang (ca. 2200–ca. 2000 B.C.).

• Read more at the Princeton University Art Museum

headline:
大汶口文化
Dawenkou Cultures
text:
Dawenkou culture takes its name from the archaeological site near the town of Dawenkouzhen in Shandong province. Dawenkou sites have been found along the eastern coast of China in the lower Yellow River valley region in Shandong and northern Jiangsu provinces, and in its later stage extends west into Henan province. Tombs of various sizes have been excavated at Dawenkou sites, and range from sparsely equipped small burials to large tombs with up to about 180 objects. Ceramics are among the myriad artifacts discovered at these sites - generally having a smooth finish, and often burnished, ceramics have been found bearing painted, carved, openwork, stamped, or applique designs; additionally, Dawenkou culture produced earthenware ceramics in myriad colors and shapes, and appear to have favored specific types of clay for different purposes (for instance, carefully washed fine clays were reserved for delicate ritual wares, while clays made of sand with a coarser grain were often used for utilitarian wares).

Radiocarbon analysis indicates a long period of cultural activity from around 4300–2400 B.C. that is commonly divided into the three following phases: Early Dawenkou (ca. 4300–ca. 3500 B.C.), Middle Dawenkou (ca. 3500–ca. 2800 B.C.), Late Dawenkou (ca. 2800–ca. 2400 B.C.).

• Read more at the Princeton University Art Museum
